Experimental conditions animal/cellular: Peripheral blood mononuclear cells were exposed to137Cs γ rays at a dose rate of 15 Gy/min.
Human lymphocytes were exposed to 1.5 Gy X-ray.
Human peripheral blood lymphocytes were exposed to 60 MeV protons or 250 kVp X-rays in the dose range 0–6 Gy, and allowed to repair DNA damage for 24 h.
DDR: No differences in radiation-induced chromosome aberrations

Experimental conditions animal/cellular: Lymphoblastoid TK6 cells were irradiated with γ rays and incubated for 24 h. Radiation doses ranged from 1–4 Gy at dose rate of 1 Gy/min from60Co γ source.
DDR: Higher frequency of micronucleated cells and mutations. Significant reduction in apoptotic cells. Increased number of cells in G1-phase

Experimental conditions animal/cellular: Human B lymphoblast cells were exposed to 300 MeV/u carbon ions.
Human lymphocytes were exposed to X-rays at 2.2 Gy/min or γ from60Co at 1 Gy/min and incubated for 24 h. Total doses were 1, 2 and 3 Gy.
Human peripheral blood cells were exposed to137Cs γ rays. The total dose was 5 Gy and the dose rate was 3.1 Gy/min.
DDR: Significantly higher number of γ-H2AX foci per nucleus. The fraction of foci-positive cells decreased slower after irradiation

Experimental conditions animal/cellular: Embryonic stem cells were exposed to 8 Gy γ rays and incubated for 0, 1 and 2 h post irradiation.
Human peripheral lymphocytes were incubated for 4 and 24 h after 0.2 and 2 Gy γ irradiation.
DDR: Decreased number of miRNAs in response to radiation exposure

Experimental conditions animal/cellular: Spermatogenic cells of male Swiss Webster mice were exposed whole body to 200 MeV/u carbon ions at an entrance dose rate of 0.5 Gy/min.
DDR: Increased DNA damage. Increased apoptotic rate and the expression levels of p53 and Bax
